review_title: Be Sure of the Department You Apply To
pros: If you're a student, it is very convenient to be able to walk to your job. They are flexible with scheduling. Gives you entry level clerical experience.
cons: Be prepared to be treated like you are at the bottom of a totem pole, and not in the loving saying of 'working your way to the top'. I didn't understand the hierarchy of many of the divisions initially until I worked there for more than a year. In total, I spent 2.5 years of my life there, only to feel like I wasn't being seen, heard, or appreciated by senior directors and the director of my division. Even after my bosses left and they put work on the students to pick up until they hired someone, which always took 6+ months (with multiple instances of my employers, yes more than one, quitting because they did not like their overseeing director) , students were not compensated for their work. Raises were nice to consider until you realize they start you at minimum wage and usually never let you get past $10. This isn't for every department, but it was the case for mine.

review_title: Great culture, turn over rate could benefit from increased benefits and salary
pros: The culture here is phenomenal; this was an entry-level job that has helped my professional career blossom from the connections and skills created here.
cons: Although I truly enjoyed my time with this company, I did have to seek alternative employment as the pay scale and promotability rate leave much to be desired. If working in Undergraduate/Graduate admissions, consider travel time and expectations to travel a con.

pros: The weather is nicer than in other parts of the country. Salaries are reasonable.
cons: The university wants to be a top research university but also wants growth — constant growth. Well, you can’t teach bigger and bigger classes of less and less prepared students while also publishing in top journals, applying for a million-dollar grants, working with countless grad students, and trying to have a life. Nothing has changed in terms of teaching loads and expectations since the university became R1. Teaching equity is abhorrent. You could be working with a gazillion grad students and still teach as many classes as the person who has no grad students. This place is also extremely conservative. The university’s leadership will bow to political demands, even when that means eroding academic freedom.

review_title: Terrific place to work.  You just can't beat the quality of the people.
pros:
The people are wonderful.  I've lived in Texas my whole life (but have travelled extensively), and not only is "southern hospitality" a real thing, but both Lubbock and Texas Tech University specifically embody that ideal.  The people are helpful, kind, and fun. 

The campus is gorgeous.  New buildings are being built around the clock.  I went to undergrad and law school at TTU, and there has not been a day in those nearly ten years that something new hasn't been in the process of being built.  

Lots of opportunity for advancement. 

Really collaborative work environment.

Lubbock is a great town.
cons:
Lubbock is great, don't get me wrong, but I'm not above sharing it's weaker points.

It truly is in the middle of nowhere.  The city itself is actually quite nice, but outside of the city there's literally nothing but farmland. Nothing ... but farmland.  That said, the city of Lubbock is quite large, and offers a variety of restaurants and venues.  Live music is available, but is not a "huge" part of the culture.  Traffic is virtually non-existent.  Crime and cost of living are low.  And Texas Tech Football is a pretty big deal.  

As far as working for the University, there's really nothing negative to say about it.  There are, of course, some politics involved, particularly in the higher executive ranks.  But by and large, this place is full of people who genuinely care for the university, love what they do, and are willing to help a total stranger.

Management will retaliate against anybody who gives honest feedback during "anonymous" "confidential" evaluations. Do not speak even if told it is for the improvement of the department. They will write reports with your name on it and what you said about whom you said it in order to haze you and retaliate against you.

pros: The position had the potential to be awesome. It was just what I was looking for on paper. I previously worked in a different department as a student and loved every minute of it. Plus, the pay was almost as much when I was a student.
cons:
My bosses were horrible. There were several times that I cried in frustration of being treated like a child. I worked there for 11 months. It turned out that the position I was in had a lot of overturn because of those bosses. They were former high school teachers with a superiority complex and treat everyone like children. It was absolutely horrible. I went to HR, and they told me I didn't fall into a protected category for harassment and advised me to quit without notice. I did.
Additionally, the pay was awful. They had been under a pay freeze for several years, and had classified the position as something much less than it was to get the budget approval. I learned that after signing on. Unfortunately, I was desperate for a job at the time.

pros: I worked in the Allen Theatre in the Student Union as a student for quite some time. I can easily say it was the best time I had working. Bosses were great and fair and worked with my schedule. The bosses will let you study in the common area (nice and quite with no distractions) if you aren't working. Got to see many musical events, plays, operas and student events. I don't know about other jobs but I am willing to bet working at the Allen Theatre is the best job on campus, bar none.
cons: Better pay for students ($9 - $10 starting off). After I left, I heard from the former bosses things changed due to Obamacare. Obamacare absolutely minimized the hours students would get (the management at the Student Union are partly to blame for for this) and if you want more hours, you would have to go to a temp agency and work for them. This is truly a case where you can thank Obama.

review_title: Texas Tech University - Pros and Cons
job_title: Senior Academic Advisor in Lubbock, TX
pros: The environment at Texas Tech is generally positive with friendly and helpful people. Students, for the most part, are nice to work with as well. People in the department you work with make all the difference to work satisfaction. If you are unhappy in your department it's generally not too difficult to get hired on in a different department, as long as you maintain positive relationships throughout the university. It is very difficult for low performers to get fired here, unless they are in the top administration.
cons: Salary is the biggest con. Once hired at the agreed upon salary, the only raises you will receive are annual cost of living, for the most part. Even if you receive a performance raise in your department, it will not be substantial. It is a State institution so change is gear-grindingly slow so the way things are structured is pretty much it. While the benefits package is probably better than at a lot of places to work, a pretty good chunk is taken out of your monthly salary to pay for it.

review_title: Community Advisor good job for a student
pros: The main benefit is the work/pay ratio. As a community advisor (CA) you will have meetings ~2 hours per week, 6 hours of office duty, and ~1 hour dealing with events. Additionally we were give "collaterals" which is just extra work. This was an extra assignment that we had to do that could take anywhere from ~2 hours per month to 3 hours per week depending on what you got.
cons: The training is terrible. Fall training takes a week, around 10-12 hours per day. Spring training which teaches you the same information takes ~4 days and 10-12 hours per day. During this time you will have other assignments that have to be completed that are very time intensive so its an inconvenient thing. Worse yet is that you have to go to training every semester rather you are a new hire or have been there for 4 years.

review_title: Good engineering school, helps build a strong network.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros: A wide selection of professors and graduate students to work with; well-equipped laboratories; a  new material characterization laboratory is about to open; nice campus and recreational facilities; unpaid internship opportunities with X-FAB Texas in town.
cons: Research seems a little hasty, lacks purpose, and seems to fall out of the big picture sometimes. Funding and financial aid opportunities are less than stellar right now (2013), but the management seems to attempt to change it.

review_title: Tech is a great employer for grad students.
pros: There are not many employers in Lubbock that can compete with Texas Tech when it comes to flexibility of schedule and opportunity. As a graduate student, there are plenty of internships, GA positions, and research assistant positions available. Also, the opportunities are pretty limited if you do not work for Tech. Unless you enjoy waiting tables or answering phones in a call center, there aren't many other large employers in Lubbock.
cons: The only downside is there may not be a job specifically supporting what you are studying, so you may end up with a job that has little to nothing to do with what you are studying.

job_title: Graduate Part-Time Instructor in Lubbock, TX
pros: The non-resident tuition waivers were really nice. Gaining residency at this school is extremely unlikely, so being able to pay in-state tuition made a huge difference.
cons: First, the contract requires that you not seek outside employment, which would be fine if they paid higher than poverty wages. It doesn't matter, however, because the workload is so heavy it makes finishing coursework on time difficult, and there is no time for a job outside. I was working 60+ hours a week on a ten hour appointment, and this only increased when I became eligible to teach and my appointment became 20 hours. All training for teaching in the classroom as an instructor was based in theory and did not actually prepare us.

pros: Great pay and great experience. The schedule is rather flexible because you are a student. If you need time off to work on school work, the professors will work with you. The work can also be very self-paced. If you are grading papers, you can work at your own pace as long as you work within the professors parameters. The pay is very nice. You get paid once a month and it is around $20 an hour. You also receive a credit for half tuition.
cons: The work can be very intense one week and very light the other. Sometimes the professors can be very vague in what they want you to do. It can be frustrating but well worth it in experience.

pros: Opportunity to move to other university departments.
cons: Management bullies rule the department.  If you are one of the 'insiders' you have nothing to worry about.  If you aren't an insider or you stand up for your own opinion, you're going to have a target on your back. Constantly undergoing restructuring suggests you can't get your stuff together.  Ask how many times the department has re-structured the organization in the past 5-10 years.  Positive environment on the outside, negative on the inside. BTW, I was an "insider" and saw and heard horrible transgressions against employees.

review_title: Long hours, long drive, low salary.

pros: Great benefits; CME allowance excellent; Great humanism; Respect to all employees of different cultures, races, & religions.
cons: Low Salary; no on call pay for midlevels in El Paso. Had to do hospital rounds after hours & lived in 50 miles away.  Long drive home; was never offered relocation money or bonuses.  Minimal support staff, MAS, Ortho tech.

pros: Autonomous work, company car. The role itself is great - helping HS seniors with apps, attending fun events, assisting with camps, etc.
cons: A lot of weekend and night events, with no overtime pay. You're locked down for camp events in Lubbock all summer. If you take PTO during that time, it's frowned upon.  Micromanagement. A lot of gossip and cliques among coworkers and management.  High turnover in every region. Career growth would be slow if any at all. Micromanagement.

review_title: Good set of values, can be a scary place to work
job_title: Residence Life Coordinator in Lubbock, TX
pros: Texas Tech was one of the first places I worked full time after earning my degree. It was always challenging and I am grateful for the colleagues and friends I made there. They offer many opportunities for advancement. Many senior level employees stick to their values and make TTU a good but challenging place to work.
cons: Bureaucracy can be a challenge there and at the time I was there, there were a great deal of changes in the president and vice-president level. This led to a lot of fear and uncertainty.

review_title: My experience at Texas Tech was very detrimental.
pros: State institution, great benefits, great environment
cons: I used to have so much respect for Texas Tech, however, with this administration of President Bailey, there has been a shift in change management.  Campus-wide, 20-somthings are being hired into critical roles that are high level and carry much areas of responsibilities.  They are replacing employees who have a vast amount of experience and replacing them with a younger age group with little or no experience.  Therefore, I suppose if you are in your 20s and with little experience, go ahead and apply for a vice president position, you are sure to get it!

cons: There are no other benefits apart from the base salary. If you end up at wrong department you might have to work really hard for those hourly pay. Again few managers are very particular about the timings which can be a headache.

cons:

-Pay for a small job, but it's considered supplementary anyway
-University is like a small government, so it's not usually efficient
-Interdepartmental work can vary just like working with a separate entity

review_title: TTU is a good place to work, and Lubbock is a friendly and generous community to live in.
pros: I have experienced some of the best opportunities of my career at TTU. It is a place where I have generally been treated fairly and kindly, and where I feel I have been able to make a real contribution.  There are a lot of good people here who work hard in collaborative and progressive ways.
cons: There are elements of the university that are highly resistant to change and have some measure of power to inhibit progressive innovation and development.

pros: The hours are flexible and the supervisors work with students if days are needed off. Works great for an graduate student who is busy with school.
cons: Student assistants are asked to be "movers" and move heavy furniture randomly without notice. Another con is the way the time sheets are handled. Employees are required to submit time sheets online to payroll and to a manager. The payroll department requests the time sheet within 2 days after the end of the pay period, but the managers requires it the day of which can be an issue if there is a lot of work to be done.

review_title: Great Place to Work for Students
pros: My hours were very flexible - if I needed to call in to spend more time working on homework or studying for a test it was no hassle. The other side of that meant that I was often called to see if I could work when I was not scheduled to - which I thought was great when I didn't have anything to do that day or needed the extra money.
cons: As with most government jobs change happens very slowly. You can suggest great ideas but it has to make it through ten people to be considered for implementation.

pros: Great work life balance , Scholarship provided for the students . Seventy five percent fee is waived off and they give a monthly stipend , which can mange your expenses
cons: There are No Cons. It depends on you how seriously you take your job, also 4 hours per day is also not a very hectic schedule which makes it easy to manage your studies as well

review_title: Great place to work and attend school.
job_title: Senior Business Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros: Great environment which supports upward mobility and is open to change. Supporting students is highly rewarding and it is the team environment which made me feel that my role was highly important and the team would suffer if I was not around.
cons: There is much change going on at Texas Tech. For some that may not be attractive. However the system is on its way to Tier I status and staff and departments are being evaluated for effectiveness and change will be constant over the next several years.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scholar in Lubbock, TX
pros: TTU offers great benefits, particularly the healthcare and the retirement benefits. I have found the human resources department to be very helpful and my department is a collegial and friendly place to work.
cons: There are no vision benefits offered. The dental insurance is just okay (not many "in-network" dentists in town). You have to live in Lubbock, which isn't as terrible a place to live as some might lead you to believe, but if you are someone who requires the benefits of an urban surrounding it's difficult to imagine you being happy here.

review_title: Lots of Work, Lots of Criticism, Little Pay
job_title: Graduate Part-Time Instructor in Lubbock, TX
pros: Full benefits for 20+ hours a week of work; Daycare program with the Child Development Center is quite nice; Very cheap to live in the surrounding area; Campus is safe
cons: Superiors not always superior in education; Heavily criticized if you do not follow the book when teaching; Students will win traditionally; Athletes are not treated as ordinary students; Pay is way less than other universities; Not enough financial resources to teach with technology in all classrooms.

review_title: Hospitality services is an ok place for students.
job_title: Student Food Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros: The hours are flexible for students. Its nice to work on campus because its close to classes. Students are not picky on food. Its also a fun way to meet with other students. Student managers are fun and even better than the full time managers.
cons: The supervisor is very unorganized. Its hard to get time off even for an exam. Other jobs on campus that pay less give you more flexible hours with school. Full time staff at hospitality services may not be the best people to have working at a university.

review_title: Lots of School Spirit but also Lots of Red Tape
job_title: Senior Business Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros: The benefits are great. The school spirit is astounding, and there were always a variety of cultural events going on. The Texas Tech Credit Union is great and I highly recommend joining it. Tech employees who used direct deposit with them got their pay a day early most of the time. The campus is well cared for, and clean. Tech is a big campus, but they have an excellent shuttle bus system.
cons:
Make sure the pay level you start at is enough for you, because once you are employed here, your pay will not rise very much at all. Sometimes it seemed  the only way to get more money was to transfer your way into a higher level position with more pay.

The parking situation for new employees means that you will most likely have to park in the commuter parking out by the credit union and ride the shuttle bus to your office. The only drawback to the bus system is that it ends around 7 p.m., so plan accordingly. Also, be sure to get your name on the waiting list right away for the parking lot you want, because it can take a long time.

Try to learn as much unofficial information as you can about a department before you take a job within that department, don't take things at face value. Try to find people who are willing to be honest about that department. Overall, the school is good, but certain departments have reputations for being difficult to work in.

If you do not work well within a bureaucratic type of organization, you should probably not apply here. There are rules for everything, and patience is required because all the correct signatures have to be gathered before some things can happen.

Individual creativity can be somewhat stifled. This is not unique to Texas Tech, though. I'm sure all large universities have the same structure.

review_title: Student Assistant job for Texas Tech Student Housing
pros: Flexible hours; you work in an on-campus residence facility (you can even request to work in the same dorm you live); you get christmas and spring breaks off; it's a great desk job to get homework done; you can bring your laptop with you or you can access the computer provided at the front desk (you can watch netflix during shifts!! HUGE PLUS); short shifts; free residence hall parking access for student assistants that live off campus (great if you're looking to score some parking for on-campus events/commuting to school/and if you want to be really sneaky, you could do laundry at the residence hall you work at for free, but I don't personally condone doing that); great alternative if you don't want to become a resident advisor/didn't get the RA position; you basically get paid to sit on your caboose 80% of the time and get $7.25/hr for it; you can EAT on the job!!! (a huge plus for me, because my stomach is the size of an elephant); part-time position; move in to campus early, so you can get comfortable and get first pick of your side/room before your roommie(s) arrive; if you work in the dorm you live in, you virtually have 24/7 access to your lock-out key and access card so you will have no marks or penalties on your lock-out card for the entire year; you would have to suck majorly or get into some serious trouble to get a bad evaluation at the end of every semester, so you basically always get a good evaluation; you can easily work this job and still rock your extracurriculars (I am in the band and go to rehearsal every day, I have a 3 hour evening rehearsal once a week, and I go to home/away games and I have had no problems getting anyone to cover/trade shifts); you don't really need to go through your supervisor first to trade/cover shifts with other assistants, just don't go over 19 hours a week; very easy to train and understand office procedures; you don't have to deal directly with the residents if they have roommate conflicts/serious issues (you just call an RA to deal anything like that); it's easy to talk to your supervisor if you have any issues with your schedule/etc; don't waste money printing your assignments at the library when you can just do it on the job; direct deposit pay; it's possible to fit in a workout video on youtube or blogilates or something in the early morning when the office is a standstill; work study available; no tax deductions from your paycheck; you can leave to go to the restroom for like 5 mins and there's freedom to move around the office if you want to so you're not completely sedentary
cons:
It's a 24/7 position, meaning there's one person in the office at any given time to deal with students that have locked themselves out of their room/emergencies/etc, so that also means everyone gets at least two "crap" shifts throughout the week (i.e. shifts that run through the weekend and asinine early shifts, like from 9pm-12am, 12am-3am, and so on), so you have to carefully schedule these shifts around your classes; you have to deal with a bit of freshman sass and drama (but that's typical of any people-oriented service); there is a student housing staff banquet at the end of every year, but all the CAs must go, so they look to the SAs to cover all of their shifts and I covered so many shifts that weekend and that was probably the most boring weekend ever in the office for me (but major green was acquired!); you NEED to learn how to speak up if a 3am-6am won't work for you on a particular day, especially if you have a bunch of hard classes later on in the day because soon enough exams will come and you know you will be sleep deprived for it if you're working a late shift and you will be stuck with that shift because NO ONE will want to take it  for you and you just have to realistically look at your schedule and think, "hmmm, will this work/school schedule make me want to pull my hair out???" (and DON'T feel bad if a shift isn't working for you because after all everyone else is thinking about themselves and the staff will have no problem taking advantage of your eagerness to take an early shift. putting your academics first is KEY); if you're not a night owl, don't take this job and just go for hospitality services; you move in to campus earlier than everyone else for scheduling and training so you're lonely for a few days; checking people in and out at the dorms at the beginning and end of each school year is fast-paced and a wee bit stressful, but basically the RAs deal with all that; you can't leave until the next person comes in for their shift and if they're late you have to stay and it might affect your schedule; it also sucks having a shift from 6-9am because when the hall secretary who is supposed to work after you calls in sick at the very last minute you have to figure out who is going to fill that position and most of the staff are going to class around that time, so that can be pretty inconvenient especially if you need to go to class after work, too; you usually get paid on a monday or a tuesday, so no pay day just before the weekend begins; you don't work more than 19 hours on this job, so don't expect a lot of dough to cover all of your expenses; don't even think about sleeping on the job because on-call hall coordinators wander in and out of the residence hall during the late hours and they need you to be alert so they can sign a check-in sheet (sometimes they will even want to have long conversations with you especially when you're sleep deprived); in my experience, my supervisor was very passive-aggressive and was very disorganized but this doesn't affect you as much as it affects the RAs; sometimes the environment can be negative when the RAs are venting and stressing out, but most RAs have the resilience to turn themselves around and come up with a solution to a problem; you have to come in 10 mins early to do the money count when you clock in and again before you clock out, so if you don't know how to count money you're screwed; you don't always have quiet time to yourself to do homework since RAs and other staff come in and out of the office as needed (some even chill out at the hall secretary's desk to watch netflix with other RAs and basically interrupt your intended study time). 

This is all I can think about, but I would definitely recommend this job if you don't mind the little quirks and are looking for flexibility.

review_title: Great people, not so great work in the Student Union Building
pros:
My co-workers were, without a doubt, some of the most fun people I've had the pleasure of working with. Despite our manual-labor oriented tasks working with the Operations Crew, we always made working pretty enjoyable, and when we weren't working, we were usually hanging out watching movies and generally just chilling down in our little cave in the basement. It was a very relaxed, college-oriented atmosphere, and if you can hang with the Crew's level of banter, you'll have no problem fitting in and making friends. 

Our superiors were also great to work for. They were understanding, accommodating to our class schedules and needs--to the point that if you needed to study for an upcoming test, they were more than willing to let you call to not come in.
cons:
As a member of the Operations Crew in the Student Union building, we were in charge of setting up rooms for functions and events, as well as some cleaning tasks such as plunging toilets (although you'd think the janitors would cover that) and cleaning the back dock. In addition, we performed general maintenance tasks such as changing light bulbs and batteries, and occasionally painting. Put simply, the tasks themselves were simple, repetitive, and to some degree, thankless, since many in the building barely even acknowledge our existence, and a reasonable pain tolerance is a must due to the number of times you'll probably drop a chair on your foot when you start out. 

I left the position, mostly because I graduated, but also during a time of change. The Operations Crew as it currently sits is being broken up into Maintenance and Setups, the first of which is a small group devoted to small repairs, the other of which is larger and devoted to only setting up rooms. This will likely change the entire formula of the job I held fairly significantly, so my review here may not be entirely accurate compared to the current situation. However, both bosses over each group are good to work for, so I believe that, while possibly more formalized, the position will still be one worth looking at. 

Finally, the pay starts (for my position) at minimum wage, with a .25 cent raise every year you work there, meaning that if you work that position for the full four years of college you're looking at a whopping one dollar more per hour than when you started, which, considering the amount of work we do doesn't seem entirely fair, especially with the knowledge that the position *used* to pay $10 an hour. Hopefully the change-up in the positions will come with an increase in pay.

review_title: Low pay, Flat organization structure, Wanna-be attitude rewards talent they can buy, not grow
pros: Lubbock has great weather, and everything you could want in a town. While real estate prices are creeping up, you can still get a lot of house for the money. The benefits at Tech are OK. Health insurance is OK. Dental insurance is poor. There is no insurance for glasses. The campus is quite beautiful. The buildings are well designed and look similar and classical. The university is trying to improve its standing, and some departments are attracting higher quality faculty members. Most buildings in very good repair and well-maintained.
cons: The pay is low, and even within departments, there are gross imbalances in work expectation and pay. For faculty members in "my generation" there was no start up money. There have been many years where there has been no travel money. At most, I have received $1000, which does not even cover one conference. I have spent over $30,000 of my one money to go to conferences and get my career kickstarted in the first decade. I never received acknowledgement for this. I have repeatedly asked for equity raises, to be told by the college dean and department chair, "Go out and get a competing offer." Meanwhile, faculty in my own department with lower rank and less experience, and fewer accomplishments, make more than I do. The university has a "flat" organization structure which means you are at the mercy of perhaps just one person over you (the department chair). No one is beholden to you, or cares about you. This results in surprising isolation. One rogue colleague or department chair can do a lot of damage. In general the university has a wanna-be Tier I attitude, which means they will buy talent rather than grow what they have.

job_title: Software Developer and IT Consultant in Lubbock, TX
pros: Good support from senior management. I found the balance is well proper for the employees working here. New opportunities to learn and develop. Small scale project but still challenging ones. Give a great exposure to different terms and conditions.
cons: Some times no clear agenda of what to do. Every company has some negative feedback but it depends person to person. i feel that if every thing is in order then we will manage it well to change for good growth

pros: University pride and traditions. AMAZING Staff! Lots of opportunity to supervise amazing, intelligent, hard working students!
cons: Long hours for low pay. You work weekends and often times holidays dependent on on call schedule. Out in the middle of nowhere, about 5-6 hours away from most big cities so doesn't always do well for the mental health of the students. Probably the worst I had seen since being a higher education professional.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros: Wonderful work-life balance, very flexible hours with school schedule, and lots of opportunity to learn.
cons: Didn't do the job I was hired to do, instead worked as a Peer Success Coach. Little direction from management (top-down issue), and ridiculously long and unnecessary meetings make it IMPOSSIBLE to get anything done.  Also, the management stifled his student employees because (it seemed) he was very self-conscious about seeming lesser than his workers, and therefore took all their credit for himself.

pros: Benefits, opportunities to advance, mentoring, and working with students.
cons: Salaries are quite a bit lower, but this is pretty much the "norm" working in higher ed, and is not exclusive to Texas Tech.  Understandably, education is important, however the disregard for experience, and the graduate degree expectation for some positions gets to be a bit much in some departments.

review_title: TTU is an awesome place to work. The people are nice, and school spirit is contagious.
pros: You can work and go to school at the same place. Supervisors are very flexible with schedules. As a student, you make your own schedule, and no one bats an eye if you have to take off one day, as long as you tell them in advance. Everyone is extremely kind and supportive.
cons: Parking is a challenge sometimes because of the cost and the number of people who work and go to school here. Parking Services can be a pain.

review_title: needed more organization and communication skills.
job_title: Senior Patient Services in Lubbock, TX
pros: great benefits, not a hard place to move up, but you can only go so far.
cons: There should of been some sort of universal uniform for all departments.  It was hard for all to determine whom was who and so forth.  HR was usually vauge on their policies.

pros:
Work with your school schedule and fairly easy work to do.
Get to work with fellow students who work through college.
cons:
Management is beyond idiotic.
Many employees are from temp agency, can lead to issues.
Students are no longer allowed to work more than 20 hours, which doesn't work for some people.
No way to move up unless you stay around a long time and wait for someone to retire

pros: The benefits are good, the people are nice, there is a lot of freedom on what you can work on.  The coworkers are quite competent.  The training is good that they do in house.
cons: It is difficult to start something new, or to innovate.  The way things are done is the way that things will continue to be done for the most part.

review_title: It is a good part time job while in school
pros: The Landmark is pretty flexible around school schedule and is willing to let me make up work hours. During the summer they provide you with lunch.
cons: The tasks become mundane and monotonous if archaeology is not a passion of yours. There is a 20 hour minimum which can be a hassle during some school weeks.

pros: The benefits they offer are great. The atmosphere of working on a college campus is always pretty special. As a state employee you get access to lots of great discounts.
cons: The university runs on a "this is how we've always done it" mantra at every level. There is a complete lack of vision, and new thoughts and ideas seem to be avoided like the plague. This leads to there seeming to be rampant disfunction at the top levels. Also be ready to navigate a political minefield.

review_title: Great People, Friendly work culture, Latest Technology
pros: People are great. No question about it. The Texas Tech University policies are outstanding. You feel very comfortable working in here because you can very well balance work/life ratio. In Technology part, you have independence to explore new stuff and you can very well gain some valuable experience here.
cons: Not much. Just that compared to any other bigger city the pay is less, But more than sufficient if you are staying Lubbock.

review_title: Great all around place to work.
job_title: Senior Business Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros: Great benefits including full medical coverage, beautiful campus, many networking opportunities, and lots of activities and events.  Friendly environment to work in.  Employees get 3 credit hours each semester free after one year of employment.
cons: Pay is low and noncompetitive. Not easy to advance your career. You have to pay for your own parking on campus, there is no guarantee that your space is near the building you work in.  Hard to take classes if working full time. OP is often vague.

pros:
1.  You will get a paycheck
2.  Nice student recreational center
cons:
1.  Constantly hear 'that's the way we do things around here'.
2.  Administrators don't walk the talk and strive for mediocrity.
3.  Tremendous waste on campus with poor recycling and much water waste.
4.  Lubbock is a stifling, ugly, conservative place full of conservative, religious folks
5.  They want to be a Tier 1 research university, but they want faculty to teach like it's a 4 year school.
6.  Small-minded attitudes prevail

pros: Great vacation and sick leave policy.  I had an office, where at other jobs I might not have had one.
cons: Everyone was required to pay for a parking pass.  I figure this should be given to employees as everyone I knew drove their car to work.  The pension was fine, but it took a very large chunk out of every paycheck.

review_title: Great place to work, nice people, and always changing.
pros: The biggest pro about for Texas Tech is that it allows me to both work and go to school in the same place. I don't need to drive back and forth all day. They are also very flexible with my schedule.
cons: The biggest problem is the parking on campus. They are very strict on where you can park, even if its not close to the building you work in, and you are still required to pay for a parking permit.

review_title: Positive experience at Texas Tech University, Plant and Soil Science Department
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros:
The Department has good computer and software infrastructure for graduate students. This includes the support of an IT specialist that believes in service and is very responsive.
The leadership, Department Chairman, is very positive and is available for meetings when requested.
The Department is well funded, with funding from USDA and commodity groups. Most, if not all, graduate student that apply receive scholarships.
cons: Department has several office locations within the Lubbock area; this makes interaction between graduate students more difficult.

review_title: So So, it needs to get better because it is just a job not a real career option
pros: Okay pay, okay benefits, easy life,

review_title: Overall a good experience as a teaching assistant and part time instructor

review_title: Texas Tech was a pretty good university to work for.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lubbock, TX

review_title: Student Manager for Hospitality Services...good college job.
pros: Flexible hours and work schedule. On campus dining was closed on holidays so I never had to worry about having breaks off.
cons: Poor management above us students. Little help with advanced customer service issues.

pros: Grew alot as a young professional. The management at the REC really cares about the students, and developing them as leaders. As a college kid employee you get what you put into the place. Got the chance to manage lifeguards and work on interpersonal skills. I improved on my leadership skills through my time at TTU Rec
cons: Dealing with lubbock local, and ttu college kid patrons.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros: This is a great place to work while you are going to school.The work is rewarding and you are always working on the leading edge of your field. It is a very respected institution. The people are incredible talented and you will learn something new everyday
cons: It doesn't pay much but it pays better than other universities, especially for engineering. There are also a lot of dust storms in Lubbock.

job_title: Senior Director, Adjunct Professor in Lubbock, TX
pros: Texas Tech has some of the most dedicated people, including faculty, staff, administrators, and, especially, students to the best education opportunities available to ALL students.  I'm very proud to be an alumni and a retiree from Texas Tech University.
cons: Because Texas Tech has grown so large over the last 30 years, it is sometimes difficult to communicate with the right person to get needed information.

pros: Great place to learn and meet people in similar fields. There was some tuition reimbursement as well.
cons: They don't pay graduate students a living wage. I had to take out more student loans each semester because I couldn't pay rent and bills on the pay they provided. Additionally even though I was classified as part time I was threatened to be fired if I took a job elsewhere.

job_title: Advertising Account Executive in Lubbock, TX
pros: Excellent learning experience and great launching pad to a steady career. Gives students a chance to interact with local business owners.
cons: One con is that you are paid solely on commission. However if you are doing your job well, this shouldn't be an issue.

review_title: Too much office politics to get anything meaningful done.
pros:
-Works around your schedule
-Provides training if you lack experience
-Offers pay raises to students
cons:
-Takes 10 emails to 5 different departments to get one thing done
-Salaries are so low only the most incompetent people apply
-Impossible to change policies

job_title: Graduate Part-Time Instructor in Lubbock, TX
pros: Wonderful and supportive work environment! They want to see you succeed and want to help you progress in your career. Flexible work hours, I get to make my own schedule.
cons: The pay is low and difficult for a Graduate student to live off of while finishing school. I am also an instructor for a class and it took the department a while to update my status.

pros: It was a decent way to financially scrape through college. They are very understanding of the craziness of a student schedule.
cons: Extremely dull at times and job duties are pretty much just anything and everything they don't feel like doing..which is very much life.

pros:
- Excellent scheduling, bosses will work with your schedule as of 2019
- Pleasant workforce, very amicable co-workers and bosses
- Free meals up to 10$ value and discounts
cons:
- Ceiling on promotions and raises, but that's to be expected. You can be at most, a student manager if a student along with the slightly extra pay and more responsibilities
- The usual problems of working retail

review_title: It is a good educational center with good job opportunities as well.
pros: The best thing about Texas Tech is that it has some wonderful job opportunities for PhDs as professors/instructors.
cons: Texas Tech has a drawback that it is in the middle of nowhere. It is far away from industrial hubs and is a small world in itself. The closest big city is Dallas which is 6 hours away!

pros: Low living cost is a definitely merit. Purchasing a house will not be a problem by working five or more years there. Commute is not a problem, only fifteen to twenty minutes maximum.
cons: Not much interesting things are there. Very far from major big cities such as Dallas, Austin, Houston, San Antonio, and Santa Fe, etc. All of them more than five and a half hours.

pros: Flexible to your class schedule, few supervisor are good to work with
cons: some times your supervisor are real pain, they don't want to understand you and treat you like they can fire you any time

review_title: Texas Tech - Great place to work in West Texas!
pros: Flexible work schedules with ample time off.  Relaxed environment.
cons: Opportunities for advancement only to a certain level.  Most higher paid positions are occupied by individuals who have been a part of Texas Tech for more than 20 years.

review_title: A professional, friendly place in the middle of nowhere
pros: Texas Tech University has a very professional and friendly environment and it is making a good a progress in state and national university rankings.
cons: Although it is a nice campus to work in, it is located in a small boring city in the middle of nowhere, where you do not have many different options to do to enjoy your free time.

review_title: I loved being a Red Raider!
job_title: Lead Academic Advisor in Lubbock, TX
pros: Excellent work environment! You are encouraged to grow as a staff member and as an individual. You have opportunities to conduct research, go to conferences, and collaborate across campus.
cons: The pay isn't as good as it could be. With a Master's Degree, I was only making $37,000. The benefits aren't great either - ultimately you only have one option for health insurance.

review_title: This is one of the best jobs a full time student could ask for!
pros:
Everyday you built relationship with children, their families, and co-workers. You could work between classes and pick up extra shifts or babysitting jobs if you desired more income.
Staff is welcoming and appreciative.
cons: Only con would be trying to get a shift covered before a long weekend.

job_title: Student IT Technician in Lubbock, TX
pros: They work with your schedule and the work environment is generally very quiet and relaxed.
cons: For the work you do, the entry pay is not worth it-- sometimes you are left with a queue full of issues and there seems to be no end to them. You are limited to working 20 hours per week.

review_title: Perfect Place To Work as an Student Assistant
pros: Students get to work in a friendly environment and also learn about work ethics. Very friendly staff. They also work really well with students schedule during exams.
cons: Salary is not that great for student assistants but still competitive. Few managers don't treat their students that well again very few of them

review_title: Working dining services at the Student Union Building at TTU
job_title: Chick Fil A in Lubbock, TX
pros: Very quick interview process, decent pay for a part time job for students, welcoming work environment, friendly staff, and free food to take home after closing.
cons: Be careful with hot oil or equipment! You may burn yourself and you may smell like fast food for the rest of the night.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros:
Get paid to earn your degree is a definite Pro. This depends heavily on the research funding. Work with plenty of bright individuals.
Most student services will always get back to you fast.
cons:
Parking. 
Some professors think that if you're in Grad school, you can handle more time-draining work when the reality is that you're too busy with your research. Try to avoid these professors.

pros:
EASY to work, every assigment is easy and fixed.no need to worry too much.
FLEXIBLE. the deadline is good, don't need to feel hurry.
cons: NO CHALLENGE. everyday is the same, nothing change. the salary is ok but not super. It will be boring sometimes.

pros: Some of the pros of working for TTU IT was learning the equipment and procedure of the ticket system and just overall knowledge of working with professors and other students.
cons: Some of the cons of the working for the IT department were management is not fond of listening to what the techs suggest for means of approaching a problem and are not timely in some manners.

pros:
Fairly agreeable management, or at least approachable.
Works with student schdules.
Not overly stressful.
cons:
Lots of different departments doing  different things without eachother's knowledge. Trying to get something fixed in a dorm room is a throwup between 4 different departments.
Definitely pay close to minimum they can get away with. Usually room for some small raises though.

job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros:
Flexible hours
Extra income as a student
Calm environment 
Able to do hw at work
Work study credit
cons: No cons for students at my specific job and location.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros:
1) Flexible work hours during the day
2) Comparable salary with industry
3) Good management to deal with

cons:
1) Bad place to live 
2) bad there is no city life
3) No salary hikes

pros:
Flexible with student hours
Shares a common passion for the school
Opens the mind to new ways of thinking and relating to others
cons: High turnover because of graduation, transfers, and the want to live off campus.  Therefore, training is required for all each semester.

review_title: Good place to focus on thesis and nurturing and supportive faculty.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros: You get out what you put in, so if you are motivated you can get a lot out of the program
cons: Limited interaction with the rest of campus as our location is about 6 miles out of town.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros: A growing university with a potential to do great research work
cons: Even though the idea of being GPTI is a great opportunity to improve communication and teaching ability, it also could be very time demanding task. Specially when you are in tight time table to graduate.

review_title: TTU would be the best place to work if degreed  staff were paid more.
pros: TTU provides great benefits and  is an overall great place to work. A lunchtime walks around the beautiful campus is always enjoyable.
cons: The pay scale is very low compared to other Texas universities and cost of living raises are rare.  Employees have to pay for their parking.

review_title: very great place for student to work
pros: time to get your work done, pleasant coworkers, interesting collection of books and artifacts. Very easy to move around job-wise within the library system. very accommodating to your school schedule.
cons: obviously the student pay is very low, but it helps to have the extra money. sometimes when things are slow, it can be boring.

pros: The people there are very laid back. The campus is beautiful. The pay is competitive with other universities. You are free to do your own thing just be ready at the deadline.
cons: Performing technical research you really need to have outside funding  for equipment to really get started. Sharing of equipment is not big there.

review_title: A good place to work, but low compensation
pros: An entrepreneurial place to work— individual initiative is encouraged and rewarded; hard-working students; a great community of colleagues among faculty, staff, and administration; tons of school pride here across all levels
cons: Not as supportive of the humanities disciplines as it is of the sciences/agriculture/business/health and pre-professional studies; low compensation relative to other universities

pros: There was a huge learning curve and I learnt a lot. The professors on the projects are very helpful professors. It is a great step before you enter the corporate world.
cons: The compensation would be bit low when compared to other companies. This is expected because it is an educational institution where the major focus is on learning.

pros: Good learning experience, friendly environment and atmosphere, good pay ranges, the infrastructure facilities are good, has other added benefits too.
cons: It is located in a very small town in the middle of nowhere called Lubbock . Igf u are from a big city, might take a while to adjust . Apart from this, not many cons.

job_title: Computer Service Technician in Lubbock, TX
pros: Allowed time to study, great for learning, (I worked for IT), nice coworkers
cons: Poor pay for the skill level, some levels of management would not discuss issues directly with you, close-minded about), poor management structure (wrong people are in charge).

review_title: It was laid back, and my boss taught me a lot.
pros: It was convenient as I was a student there, and a great way to earn extra income.
cons: Lubbock is not the most fun place to live, but a great place to go to School. I didn't have a problem with management directly, and Texas Tech hires great people.

pros: Good starting job if you are from out of town, multiple job titles available for students looking for a job that are from out of town
cons: Little room for promotion, hard work doesnt get noticed some times, outside help hired by texas tech can be hostile to students

pros:

job_title: Graduate Part-Time Instructor in Lubbock, TX

pros: Pros is that it an easy job that is convenient for students. You are able to do homework, and only have to work 3 days of the week.

review_title: Research and teaching assistant in the accounting department.

review_title: TTU is an Extra ordinary work place

review_title: The WORST place to work EVER!!!! The are terrible to their staff!!!!

review_title: Rigid bureaucracy, but a lot of good opportunities

pros: Flexible hours and the shifts stay the same weekly. they know we are students first and get that we have projects and tests

review_title: I feel everything was very  well Organize

pros: good environment and nice culture. You have good knowledge and freedom to work. Career wise nice opportunity to start at! Good company.
